content:
Happiness.
For decades, we’ve chased it like something lost, something to discover out there in the world.
But true happiness isn’t found. It’s built. And it can only be built by us especially from within.
We can’t force it by constantly thinking about it. Instead, we stay happy by choosing a lifestyle of happiness: That is quietly eliminating toxic thoughts that create toxic realities.
When we let go of negativity, space opens for peace.
As the Buddha beautifully said:
Move your thoughts from competition to contribution then your life becomes a celebration.
A small shift in perspective can change everything.
What toxic thought will you release today?
Prakash Ayyanagoudar

content:
We often think our struggles, questions, and quiet longings are ours alone.
But the more I open up about my own doubt, wonder, grief, hope, and the suffering of spirituality the more I realize how much we share.
This space is for those in-between moments: the emotions we can’t quite name, the spiritual stirrings that don’t fit neat boxes, the slow, messy growth that happens in silence.
If you’re here, chances are you’re walking a similar path. I write these reflections not because I have answers, but because I’ve lived the questions may times and sometimes, knowing someone else has felt the same can make the journey feel less heavy.
You’re not alone in the vague.
Thank you for being here.
— Prakash Ayyanagoudar
title: Hello, :)

content:
Hope is that quiet force giving us a reason to live,
to laugh,
to love,
to stay happy, even when everything feels heavy.
For a beggar, hope is the key to facing another day.
For a patient, it’s the strength to hold on for tomorrow.
One of my favorite stories about hope:
All the villagers gathered to pray for rain after a long drought. Everyone came empty-handed… except one boy who brought an umbrella.
That’s hope.
In this chaotic world, we long for normal days as past and those simple smiles, ordinary routines, a life like before.
Yet it’s this very hope that keeps us moving forward.
In hopelessness, hope is the light we carry inside.
— Prakash Ayyanagoudar

content:
Most of the time,
“The problem is not a problem, it is how we see the problem that is the problem.”
The solution always lies within us. A positive mind, a soul with positive vibes, can transform any challenge.
Remember:
“A positive mind has a solution for every problem, but a negative mind has a problem with every solution.”
A single positive thought creates a positive frequency.
It builds an aura of calm and possibility, leading to a truly positive mind.
Just mind your thoughts and become infinite.
—Prakash Ayyanagoudar

content:
This space is my quiet corner of the internet, a place to embrace the beauty in vagueness and the clarity in knowing better.
Know the Better is the personal side: Reflections on emotions, spirituality, growth, and the subtle mysteries of life.
Most of us walk similar paths: facing uncertainty, seeking meaning, healing old wounds, and discovering quiet moments of clarity.
These writings come from my own journey through the vague and undefined spaces of being human.
If you’re here, you’re probably feeling some of the same things.
My hope is that these words remind you you’re not alone, and perhaps make the road feel a little lighter, a little more familiar.
We’re all figuring it out together. Here I share my inner journey, moments of doubt, wonder, and quiet insight.
MindSecSet is the personal side:
Sharing my career journey in cybersecurity and technology.
Along the way, I’ve learned, unlearned, and relearned countless lessons.
About tools, threats, best practices, mindset shifts, and what truly drives professional growth in this fast-evolving field.
I will start posting initially about cybersecurity basics and we will gradually reach current trends as well along with time.
These writings are raw reflections on building expertise, overcoming setbacks, and staying ahead.
If you’re on a similar path whether starting out, pivoting, or leveling up. I hope these insights make your journey a little clearer, more confident, and less isolating.
We’re all securing our own paths, one lesson at a time.
This isn’t about having all the answers. It’s about asking better questions, staying curious, and growing one vague step at a time.
Thanks for being here. Feel free to subscribe or reach out.
— Prakash Ayyanagoudar
